featured_items.title: Letter, Hannah Arendt to Heinrich Blücher, Paris, France, February 15, 1937. Arendt met Blücher (1899-1970) in Paris in 1936. They married in Paris on January 16, 1940.

Note, Clement Greenberg, Contemporary Jewish Record (Commentary), New York, N.Y., January 16, 1945, regarding publication of Hannah Arendt’s article on stateless people. Greenberg (1909-1994) was associate editor of Commentary from 1945 to 1957.

Hannah Arendt Blücher, U.S. certificate of naturalization, New York, N.Y., December 10, 1951. Arendt and husband Heinrich Blücher escaped to the United States from Nazi-occupied France with help from the Emergency Rescue Committee. They arrived in New York in May 1941.

Letter, Rose Feitelson, International Council of Jewish Women, to Hannah Arendt, New York, N.Y., April 18, 1957. Feitelson (d. 2001) aided Arendt as a new immigrant to the United States during World War II, helping her develop and refine her English language skills and edited many of her writings.
Hannah Arendt, typed manuscript introduction to the third edition of The Origins of Totalitarianism, 1966.
Letter, Hannah Arendt to W. H. Auden, New York, N.Y., February 14, 1960, on the teachings of the Gospels, Christian charity, forgiveness and judicial pardon.

Hannah Arendt, “Karl Jaspers: Citizen of the World,” undated draft. German-Swiss philosopher and professor Jaspers (1883-1969) was Arendt’s dissertation advisor at the University of Heidelberg and a longtime mentor and friend.

Robert Lowell, typed draft translation/interpretation of Rainer Maria Rilke’s poem Taube, die drauuseen blieb (“Pigeons”) dedicated to Hannah Arendt, enclosed in letter, January 9, 1961. Included in Lowell’s collection, Imitations.

Police examination of Adolf Eichmann (1906-1962), Nazi administrator of Jewish detention and the Holocaust. Hannah Arendt covered his war crimes trial in Israel for The New Yorker and in 1963 published Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil.

Letter, Mary McCarthy to Hannah Arendt, Paris, France, March 13, 1963, praising Arendt’s Adolf Eichmann pieces for The New Yorker. Novelist and critic McCarthy (1912-1989) was part of the Partisan Review and New Yorker intellectual circles of New York.

Hannah Arendt, “Political Experiences in the Twentieth Century” course syllabus and notes, Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y., Fall Term, 1965. Over a long academic career, Arendt taught at many American universities, including the University of Chicago, Princeton University, and the New School of Social Research.

Letter, Dwight MacDonald to Hannah Arendt, London, England, October 22, 1960, mentioning Bertrand Russell’s activism in the nuclear disarmament movement. Cultural critic MacDonald (1906-1982) was a frequent essayist for The New Yorker and the New York Review of Books.
Letter, Norman Podhoretz to Hannah Arendt, September 8, 1958, regarding the inspiration he received from Arendt’s The Human Condition.

Hannah Arendt, “Walter Benjamin” (in German), ca. 1966-1968. Arendt played a major role in the posthumous appreciation of the German-Jewish aesthetic theorist, literary critic, philosopher and essayist Benjamin (1892-1940).
Hannah Arendt, “Civil Disobedience,” page one of lecture, 1970.
Flyer for Hannah Arendt series of three public lectures on “Thinking,” sponsored by the University of Chicago Committee on Social Thought, undated.
Letter, Philip Roth to Hannah Arendt, June 26, 1975, regarding his promotion of Eastern European literature.
“21 Nobel Laureates” political statement of the Academic Committee on Soviet Jewry, printed in The New York Times, October 1, 1972.

Photograph, German abstract expressionist artist Carl Heidenreich (1901-1965), [New York], 1965. Arendt assisted in a retrospective memorial exhibition of Heidenreich’s paintings and watercolors in 1971.

Telegram, Lillian Hellman to Hannah Arendt, Paris, France, May 14, 1974, sending get well wishes after Arendt’s heart attack while lecturing on “The Life of the Mind” in Scotland in May 1974. Arendt died of another heart attack in New York on December 4, 1975.

description: Copyright in Hannah Arendt’s unpublished papers in this Collection has been dedicated to the public, with the important exception of papers which, at the time of her death in 1975, were the subject of contracts with publishers, including Harcourt Trade Publishers, New York, NY. All other Arendt writings in this Collection are free to use and reuse.

description: A brief chronology of the key events in the life and career of political philosopher Hannah Arendt (1906-1975).
children.title: Hannah Arendt Timeline

children.meta_description: An essay on Hannah Arendt and her concepts of the nature of evil by Arendt scholar and trustee Jerome Kohn.
children.title: Evil: The Crime against Humanity

children.meta_description: An essay on Hannah Arendt and her theories on the origins and practice of totalitarianism by Arendt scholar and trustee Jerome Kohn.
children.title: Totalitarianism, the Inversion of Politics

children.meta_description: To enter the world of Hannah Arendt is to encounter the political and moral catastrophes of the twentieth century. An essay by Arendt scholar and trustee Jerome Kohn.
children.title: World of Hannah Arendt

description: Copyright in Hannah Arendt’s unpublished papers in this Collection has been dedicated to the public, with the important exception of papers which, at the time of her death in 1975, were the subject of contracts with publishers, including Harcourt Trade Publishers, New York, NY. All other Arendt writings in this Collection are free to use and reuse.

items.description: Born, Hannover, Germany.

figures.caption: Hannah Arendt, with her mother, Martha Arendt Beerwald, 1912. Courtesy of the Hannah Arendt Trust.

items.title: 1906, Oct. 14

items.description: Ph.D., Heidelberg University, Heidelberg, Germany.

Published Der Liebesbegriff bei Augustin (Berlin: Springer Verlag).

Married Günther Stern (divorced 1937).

figures.caption: Günther Stern and Hannah Arendt, ca. 1929. Courtesy of the Hannah Arendt Trust.

items.description: Moved to Paris, France.
Secretary general, Youth Aliyah, Jewish Agency for Palestine, Paris, France.
Special agent for rescue of Jewish children from Austria and Czechoslovakia.

Married Heinrich Blücher (died 1970).

Sent to an internment camp, Gurs, France.

figures.caption: Hannah and Heinrich Blücher, New York, ca. 1950. Courtesy of the Hannah Arendt Trust.

items.description: Emigrated with her husband to the United States, and settled in New York, N. Y.
Journalist.
Research director, Conference on Jewish Relations.
Chief editor, Schocken Books.
Executive director, Jewish Cultural Reconstruction.

Published The Origins of Totalitarianism (New York: Harcourt, Brace).

Became a United States citizen.
Awarded Guggenheim Fellowship.
Delivered Christian Gauss lectures, Princeton University, Princeton, N. J.
National Institute of Arts and Letters grant.
Visiting professor, University of California, Berkeley.

figures.caption: Hannah Arendt lecturing in Germany, 1955. Courtesy of the Hannah Arendt Trust.

items.description: Delivered Walgreen Foundation Lecture, University of Chicago, Chicago, Ill.
Published Rahel Varnhagen, the Life of a Jewess; translated from the German by Richard and Clara Winston (London: Published for the Leo Baeck Institute by the East and West Library).
Published The Human Condition (Chicago: University of Chicago Press).
Visiting professor, Princeton University, Princeton, N. J.
Visiting professor, Columbia University, New York, N. Y.

Visiting professor of humanities, Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill.

Published Between Past and Future (New York: Viking Press).

Fellow, Center for Advanced Studies, Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn.

course notes

Published Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil (New York: Viking Press).

Eichmann in Jerusalem, typescripts for the book and the version published in the New Yorker, 1963

Published On Revolution (New York: Viking Press).

On Revolution (New York: Viking Press)
Professor and visiting lecturer, Committee on Social Thought, University of Chicago, Chicago, Ill.
Received Sigmund Freud Prize of the German Akademie für Sprache und Dichtung.
University professor of philosophy, New School for Social Research, New York, N.Y.
Published Men in Dark Times (New York: Harcourt, Brace & World).

Awarded Emerson-Thoreau Medal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

lecture
Associate Fellow, Calhoun College, Yale University, New Haven, Conn.
Published On Violence (New York: Harcourt, Brace & World).
Published Crises of the Republic (New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich).
Member, Advisory Council of the Department of Philosophy, Princeton University, Princeton, N. J.
Delivered Gifford Lectures, University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, Scotland.

Awarded Sonning Prize in Denmark.

speech
Died, New York, N. Y.

figures.caption: Hannah Arendt, just prior to her death in 1975. Courtesy of the Hannah Arendt Trust.

items.title: 1975, Dec. 4

items.description:
Posthumous publication of The Jew as Pariah, edited with an introduction by Ron H. Feldman (New York: Grove Press).

Posthumous publication of The Life of the Mind (New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich).

Posthumous publication of Lectures on Kant's Political Philosophy, edited with an interpretive essay by Ronald Beiner (Chicago: University of Chicago Press).

Kant lectures delivered at the New School for Social Research, 1970
Posthumous publication of Essays in Understanding, 1930-1954, edited by Jerome Kohn (New York: Harcourt, Brace & Co.).

Posthumous publication of Love and Saint Augustine, edited and with an interpretive essay by Joanna Vecchiarelli Scott and Judith Chelius Stark (Chicago: University of Chicago Press).

Publication of Hannah Arendt/Heinrich Blücher: Briefe 1936-1968, edited and with an introduction by Lotte Kohler (Munich: Piper. 596 pp.); translated into English by Peter Constantine and published in 2000 as Within Four Walls: The Correspondence between Hannah Arendt and Heinrich Blücher, 1936-1968 (New York: Harcourt. 459 pp.)
